description: From play +‎ ground. Compare Middle English playstede (“playground”) from Old English pleġstede.

entries.meaning: (outdoors) A large open space for children to play on, usually having dedicated play equipment (such as swings and slides). [1780]
examples: The kids have to go to the playground during recess, no matter the weather.
The local council have set up a new playground, equipped with slides, swings, and a climbing wall.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) Any physical or metaphysical space in which a person or organization has free rein to do as they please.
examples: The exclusive tropical island was a millionaire's playground.
